thread.title: Vital that business and universities unite: Julia Gillard
thread.title_full: Vital that business and universities unite: Julia Gillard | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: Vital that business and universities unite: Julia Gillard
text:
VIDEO: How Australian start-ups can achieve world domination
GRAPHIC: How does Australia compare with the rest of the world?
QUIZ: How much do you really know about startups?
Former prime minister Julia Gillard has described entrepreneurship as the future of the Australian economy, telling a group of start-ups in Melbourne that the disconnect between the business and the education sector threatens to hamstring Australia’s future.
Speaking at the StartupGrind Melbourne event, in her role as chancellor of online education provider Ducere, Ms Gillard said a strong partnership between business and education was a large element of Silicon Valley’s success.
“There will always be some things about scale that the US has that we don’t, but of all the things that went together to make Silicon Valley, it was higher ­education (that was most important),’’ she said.
“It was great universities actually being engaged and incubating with doors open and ideas flowing. One of our big problems is that we’ve got smart people and they invent really amazing stuff, but it never percolates through to the business community or the entrepreneurship community.
“There’s no exchange between that community and the universities about ‘what next’.”
Ms Gillard said Australia’s educators needed to better communicate the benefits of studying science, technology, engineering and mathematics, to stay on par with competitors.
“Those skills are such a great enabler in our age of big data and technology. If your workforce falls behind in those skills, then you leave your economy behind,” she said.
Ducere, Latin for “to lead’’, ­offers online business and management courses to students worldwide and counts former CIA director-general David ­Petraeus, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Visy executive Jeanne Pratt and fellow former PM John Howard among its global faculty.
Ms Gillard was appointed chancellor in February.
“I think entrepreneurship and higher education have collided,” Ms Gillard said. “The university world is being disrupted, and there’s also a change in skills ­acquisition. Schooling hasn’t felt all of that change yet, and we’re too reliant on the same models of education that were there when I was in school, and when my parents were in school.”
The former PM said the penny had finally dropped in Canberra about technology-driven disruption, saying that Australia’s political class “generally understands how disrupted our world now is”.
“Maybe they don’t have as clear a focus as we would like of those opportunities, but they do sense there are opportunities,” she said.
Despite recent reports highlighting the threat of automation, Ms Gillard said non-repetitive manual work was safe for now.
“Routine non-manual work, so stock market reports, reading resumes and all of that will be done by machines quite soon,” she said. “But non-repetitive, manual work, so hairdressing and caring for the elderly, will be safe.
“You’ll have to be inquiry based, in multidisciplinary teams on that edge we refer to as entrepreneurship.”
